messageBody:
Thanks Andrew.



The example you provided was a great help.

I have another related question though:

If the class that your are creating a wrapper for (in our example NetworkInterface) has static methods, your forced to leave these static methods out of the interface because you can't declare a static method in a interface. This would mean that these methods can't be included in your mock object.

I would imagine that this is a bad thing. Is there a way to work around this problem?



Regards,

Pico

You got it. The real implementation wrapper is so simple in that all it
does is delegate, that we can decide to not even test IT if we like.
What we are testing is the rest of the code that will call IT.

public interface MyNetworkInterface {
// all method that I'm currently interested in using.

public void OneOfTheInterfaceMethods() ;
}

public class MyNetworkInterfaceImpl implements MyNetworkInterface {

public void OneOfTheInterfaceMethods() {
delegate.OneOfTheInterfaceMethods() ;
}

private NetworkInterface m_delegate = new NetworkInterface();
}



public class MockMyNetworkInterfaceImpl implements MyNetworkInterface {

public void OneOfTheInterfaceMethods() {
wasOneOfTheInterfaceMethodsCalled = true;
}

public boolean wasOneOfTheInterfaceMethodsCalled() {
return m_wasOneOfTheInterfaceMethodsCalled;
}

private boolean wasOneOfTheInterfaceMethodsCalled;
}


One other thing to keep in mind, is how does your application code know
which class to instantiate.

Typically a (protected) factory method can be used or an
AbrstractFactory pattern applied.

I then create a class that implements this interface and uses the real NetworkInterface behind the scenes (a wrapper). I can then create a mock class of this wrapper. I would also replace all instances of NetworkInterface with MyNetworkInterfaceWrapper.

>>In particular I found this statement from
>>http://www.mockobjects.com/DynaMock.html:
>>"We have found that mocking third party classes (and
>>interfaces) over which we have no control causes problems in
>>the long run. It is better to define an interfaces for your
>>objects in terms of concepts in your application, and then
>>implement them as wafer-thin adapters to the third party
>>libraries. That has two benefits: (a) your objects are easier
>>to understand, and (b) your application is not polluted with
>>references to third party packages that might have to be
>>replaced for non-technical reasons. You do not need to have
>>full control over the entire codebase to follow this approach."

>>I don't really understand what is meant by this.
